content.description: This is the tiny seam that branches to the left from Test Piece.
content.protection: Very small gear and a few hands sized cams for the beginning. Small brass nuts work very well in the seam.

content.description: Start at Unconquerable base and once inside the offwidth move right and diagonal up to Squeeze Cheese anchors on other side of squeeze chimney. Think like an inch worm.
content.protection: Large cams and big bro #4 very useful.
content.location: Start at unconquerable, end at squeeze cheese anchor.

content.description:
Located in the right section of Buck's Bar dome, this climb ascends a broken crack system on the left side that heads up about 15' to a large rest where you can eat lunch if you're so inclined. A commiting almost roof move brings you into avery wide vertical crack, which is very obvious from below.

An excellent route, and the commiting move is scary, but doable, especially with protection.
content.protection: smaller (to 3") on the bottom, big stuff (up to 5"+) on the top.To set up a top rope, walk around to the top of Buck's Bar Dome, and over to the top of the climb,where you will find 2 top anchors. Choose your fancy, but you should bring some longer quickdraws or a short sling to get your anchor over the edge.

content.description: Although Truscuit Rock offers a few face climbs, the farthest left is the most classic. Start with your hands on a slopey jug and work your way up on small edges until you are standing on it. Delicate edging on slopey holds leads to the top of the block.
content.protection: Toprope from the Bat Roof anchor.
content.location: Triscuit Rock is the 20' tall block on the right side of the Great Chimney.

content.description:
Climb up the less than vertical crack in the right corner of the main area.

Sustained, this route gives excellent liebacks and jams the whole way up the crack. Trusting your feet on the excellent granite of Buck's Bar Dome is a must, but you can make it to the top!

This route shares a top anchor with Adhesion (5.10c with variations more difficult) just to the right on the face and rounded arete.
content.protection:
Pro up to 2 1/2" will suffice.

To set up a toprope: You can access the top anchors by walking around to the top of Buck's Bar Dome via the exit path to the left.

content.description: Crux comes on the lower portion of the climb. Lieback the lower flake facing right, then take a breather and lieback the upper chimney while facing left
content.protection: Top rope from two-bolt anchor above. Can be lead with larger pieces.
content.location: The chimney left of Unconquerable (5.8). Lower from anchor or rap down.

content.description:
Cottrell lists the "Rotten Face" (10+) as the wall on the left side of the Great Chimney, climbing directly to a set of anchors just north of Bat Roof. The face is indeed rotten and not too fun to climb... However, chimneying the whole feature is great, and definitely way harder than the Great Chimney (5.4) that shares anchors with Bat Roof.

Give it a consensus grade, it was many years ago we climbed it.
content.protection: Separate set of anchors.
content.location: Left side, just after Bat Roof.

content.description: A short climb with an incredible mix of powerful and balance moves. Thin crimps straight up from the start until an interesting undercling on a flake, then trend left and up to the obvious crack and anchors. The rock is very sharp and somewhat crumbly. The crux of the route is probably getting on it.
content.protection: Bolted TR anchor. Setup from above by hopping across gaps in rocks. Recommend using caution and perhaps a belay down from the main rock to the bolts.
content.location: The start of this route is on the bat wall, above (and behind) Triscuit Rock.  Climb Triscuit rock, then turn around after you top out. Look for the beginning crimp and huge foot above the first boulder towards the back of the cave. Getting on is probably the hardest move, as it can be difficult to balance on the slightly overhanging wall.

content.description: After mounting the Candy Corn Boulder you will be standing beneath two obvious large knobs on a steep face with a ramp/large flake on your right.  Not using the ramp, mantle the knobs and continue straight up on smaller knobs.  Avoid exiting right towards the top which is easier.  To make a longer, more moderate route continuing up from the Candy Corn Boulder, use the ramp/large flake to mount the two large knobs and then continue straight up (5.8 or 5.9) or once on knobs, angle right a bit to an obvious large hold to mount the top (5.7). IMHO, this is how the route should be described with the 5.10+ mantle being a variation.  Which way was the first ascent done...?
content.protection: Popcorn, according to Rock Climbs of Placerville by William H. Cottrell, is the top half of rock above Candy Corn Boulder. Popcorn is usually toproped as the protection is nil up there. There are two bolts as anchors left of Popcorn at the top of Beginner Cracks but these anchors make for a pendulum left if you come off on the face.  There may be anchors to trees where long slings would be necessary.

content.description: Stay out of squeeze chimney and avoid the arete as long as you can until the last six feet or so. Big start into delicate face climbing and a reachey traverse that can be helped with high feet and a bad crimp(the crux).
content.protection: Top-rope from bolts on the left of the arete flake.
content.location: Left face of the arete, opposite from Fingerprint; immediately right of the squeeze. Seems like it goes 11ish but I can't find the name or info anywhere.

content.description: Lieback up this oddly shaped arete between two chimneys. A fun sequence of moves because of the wandering nature of this feature, but a tad on the short side; the first part of the climb is scrambling up stacked boulders and walking a giant ledge to the start of the actual arete.
content.protection: Toprope off the bolted anchor shared with the chimneys on either side of it.
content.location: In the back of the Great Chimney, between the squeezing Chamberlain's Chimney to the left, and  dark Khazam Dum to the right.

content.description: The Great Chimney can be chimneyed at various places for different widths and grades of difficulty.
content.protection: TR only. Use bolts above Squeeze Cheeze, Bat Cracks, Bat Roof, or other routes.
content.location:
The largest, most obvious, usually shady chimney on the left side of the Main Area.

I sorted this route to favor borrowing the anchors from Squeeze Cheeze. This is the simplest and safest way to toprope the Great Chimney.

content.description: Fly or Die lies on the right side of the Main Area, just left of the easier climb Beginners Cracks.  Start beneath the obvious downward and left facing flake.  A long reach up and over left to the bottom of the crescent flake is the crux of the climb.  Thin face climbing leads from the crescent up to knobs to the top.  There are several fun variations for the upper section.  From the crescent flake, step left onto the blank face.  Move left another move or so to the small knobs and climb straight up (5.10+).  Instead of going up to the small knobs, continue left further on even blanker terrain and then straight up (5.11). Another variation is from the crescent, traverse to the arête's face on the right and up (5.10).  Using the arête's edge makes this trivial.  This is a fun climb as the beginning is steep and strenuous and the remainder is delicate face climbing.
content.protection: Fly or Die cannot be protected after the first 8' so toproping makes sense.  There are two bolts for anchors on the top.

content.description:
This route ascends the very slightly featured face and arete just to the left of Unconquerable. Climb up the face or arete using one of many approaches to an interesting traverse or direct move that's going to be dynamic unless you're really in tune with your balance. Most of the route is less than vertical, though the tougher beginning section both vertical, and void of good foot placements.

This route is tough for about 8 feet, from about 4 feet off the ground until about 12 feet, and then a considerably simpler, yet enjoyable trek for the rest of the route.

An easier variation is possible by starting on Unconquerable, then traversing left halfway through to a "jug" on the arete as shown in the topo. Finish on the face with left and scooting up the arete. Goes at about 5.11.
content.protection: 2 bolts above, which can be accesed by climbing onof many other easier traditional routes in thearea, or by walking around to the top via the path.

content.description: Chamberlin's Chimney is the squeeze chimney in the back left side of the Great Chimney. It starts by scrambling up piled blocks from ground level, walks a ledge to below the anchor bolts, then squeezes up Chamberlin's Chimney proper. Climbed as an offwidth Cottrell gives it 5.9, as a lieback 5.7.
content.protection: Wide stuff? I've only toproped this line. Two bolt anchor up top.
content.location: The crack formed by the left side of the Finger, on the left side of the Main Area, just right of the Great Chimney.

content.description: Candy Corn Boulder starts just right of Beginner's Cracks where two obvious large crack systems angle towards each other and meet about 12' up.  Climb left, right, or both to get to easier ground above.  I gave this a one star as if you try various starts, you get lots of practice using different crack techniques.  By using just the left crack, or just the right crack, or using both cracks, all go at 5.7 or so.  Jamming the right crack as a straight-in hand jam goes at 5.9. A good finish to this climb continues up on ramp/large flake above to where you can step left onto the large knob on face.  Angle up and right for an easier finish (5.7) or step left further on the two large knobs and continue straight up as on the finish of Popcorn (5.10a depending on height).
content.protection: Candy Corn Boulder is usually done as a toprope but the climb could be protected with medium to large pro up to the beginning of Popcorn but is probably not worth it.  Leading up even the easy variation of Popcorn would be run out.  Anchors on the top of Beginner's Cracks could be used for toproping this climb.

content.description:
Beginner's Cracks are on the right side of the Main Area of Bucksbar Dome.  They are just to the left of the candycorn.  There are several variations of the climb, all of which share a 5.2 start.

1) Corner Only - 5.6.  Follow the obvious corner to the left the whole way up, staying off of the knobs on the face.  Climb tops out to the left as you come out of the corner.

2) Small Knobs On Face - 5.8.  Follow the knobs that go up between the corner and the crack.  Use the face features only.

3) Two Cracks 5.6/7 - Follow the 2 parallel cracks to the off width.  Tops out at 2 bolts at the top of the crack.  The large left crack is 5.6.  The smaller right crack is 5.7.  A 5.8 variation can be made by skipping the big knob midway up the off width crack.
content.protection:
All variations can be top roped from one of two sets of 2 bolt anchors that are easily accessed from the top of the right side of Main Area on Bucks Bar Dome.

The 5.2 start to all variations doesn't take a lot of gear (a 4" piece may work, but is not necessary), but there is a good stance at the end of the 5.2 section to protect above.

Corner Only - Takes 1" to 2.5" and is rather difficult to protect at the top where it gets bigger.  Use slings to reduce drag on the lower pieces in the corner.

Two Cracks - 1/2" to 1.5".  The lower portion takes good gear in the right crack.  The upper portion is a nice off width that will take a few pieces, although they take up the best holds in the crack!

content.description: Start on half-pad crimps on the gently-overhanging face directly under the Bat Roof. A couple burly moves on small edges lead to larger holds and easier ground. A fall here will throw you backwards into "Triscuit Rock." Climb straight up to the bottom of the roof and finish on Bat Roof. A two-move wonder, and an often overlooked climb.
content.protection: Top Rope from the Bat Roof anchor.
content.location: On the face directly below a vertical seam that leads to the underside of the Bat Roof.

content.description:
Climb trends right on finger ledges to an undercling roof and a convenient ramp up to the top. Cool in the hot weather, can be chimneyed with the opposite wall for an easier climb.

Direct variation (5.11) goes directly up to the undercling roof
content.protection: Bolted TR anchor setup from above by hopping across gaps and careful downclimbing.
content.location: In the Great Chimney area behind the Great Flake.

content.description: Slightly overhanging liebacking on jugs leads to a ledge. Mount the ledge and follow a right-leaning crack to its end. From here, cut up and left to the Bat Crack Left anchor. The overhanging block of the Bat Roof is OFF; using it lowers the grade significantly.
content.protection: Top rope from the Bat Crack anchor. Rap in from the Bat Roof anchor.
content.location: On the left, slightly overhanging wall of the Great Chimney area.

content.description:
Climb the arete at the mouth of the Bat Cave aka Great Chimney. Hug the twin cracks on each side of the arete, then break left for thin hands and fingers through the vertical and slightly overhung finish. Supposedly there is a no-hands rest here.

Warning- slimy and appropriately named, there may be bat guano in this crack.
content.protection: TR from above with a careful setup- bring a second line or rope to descend to the two bolt anchor. Alternatively, lead with gear to 1 inch.
content.location: Left side of the arete at the mouth of the Great Chimney aka Bat Roof. About 15 feet left of Unconquerable pillar.

climbs.name: Adhesion
climbs.fa: UC Davis Outdoor Adventure program climbers, ca.1975

content.description:
Climb up the featured face, which is almost a rounded arete just to the right of

Test Piece

(5.8), and sharing the same top anchor.

Start on the flake at the arete, and work your way up to an interesting sidepull move 20 or so feet off the ground.There are a couple of variations to this route, by keeping the good hand to the right of the sidepull off, this route is probably a 5.11a. By working without the reachy move to the dish on the left about 15 feet off the ground, this route is probably a 5.11d.

Enjoy some interesting foot moves in the bottom, and interesting balance moves up top.
content.protection:
2 bolts are conveniently set at the top of

Test Piece

(5.8), which is the corner crack route just to the left of Adhesion. You can also walk around to the top of Buck's Bar Dome by walking around to the path on the left side of the rock.
